Note that when I refreshed the offending project my decorators came back just fine.

This is expected. 

Question, what would be the best option for handling exceptions in the decorator:
1. silently ignore
2. log
Those are really the only options and we found that (2) was 
the right thing to do.

The problem was that decorators were disabled everywhere as a result of the 
exception so it was in way obvious that this was a problem. I would decorate 
with something different to indicate there was a provlem.

If we think logging in the right action, then we shouldn't log the stacktrace 
as it is not of any use. Another option would be to refresh the file (we may 
still want to log that we did it). We could use Tod's suggestion of an 
alternate decorator but this would need to be placed either on the parent 
folder or on all resources in the folder. Another possibility is a marker on 
the folder. I like the auto-refresh idea myself.

>> I like the auto-refresh idea myself.

But then the builders will run, which is a bit unexpected a side effect from 
decorating.  Decorating shouldn't change the state of the workspace.

Instead, we can get the contents using the force flag. No workspace lock, no 
build, just the file contents.
